thermalsight: A monster with thermalsight can see living creatures through darkness and heavily obscured conditions, such as fog. The monster can also determine if a creature is living or dead though its body heat. However, the monster can't discern color, nor use this sense to see through illusions, invisibility, or magical darkness. This sense is blocked by one inch of any solid barrier. Many constructs have this special sense.

Data: This new skill in Dark Matter governs how well one can manipulate a technological interface and gain access to information or other functions. Your Intelligence (Data) check encompasses your knowledge of software and its exploits, more than hardware (which is covered by the Technology skill), and so will only be used when you use technology that has an interface, like a datapad, an arcane terminal, a ship's computer, or other control technology, like a door control or the computers that govern a {@item shield generator|darkmatter} or ship weapon. If a piece of technology doesn't have an interface, an interface rig is required to interact with it. The GM should call for an Intelligence (Data) check whenever you attempt complicated operations on a data system, when you attempt to reprogram a construct, or when you attempt to hack a device.

Any sort of illegal or unauthorized access to a technological system is called Hacking and requires the use of an {@item interface rig|darkmatter}, as well as an Intelligence (Data) check. In general, a hacking attempt requires 1 minute of work using the technology, though the GM can decide that certain tasks might take only an action. On a successful check to hack a device, you can perform operations on the system as if you had full access. On a failed check, roll a d6. On a 6, the device locks down and no further attempts can be made to hack it. More secure devices might lock on a roll of 5 or 6, or on a roll of 4 to 6, as determined by the GM. You can hack into devices to illegally access a security system, open a door, disable an alarm, or manipulate someone else's datapad to give you access to their information or bank account.
Piloting: A new skill in Dark Matter, your Dexterity (Piloting) check covers how well you maintain control over a ship in difficult circumstances. You don't need proficiency in Piloting to fly a ship (be it an aircraft or a spacecraft), but proficiency in this skill can help when you need to make a crash landing or pull off a risky maneuver in a dogfight. The GM might call for a Dexterity (Piloting) check when you attempt to fly a ship through an electromagnetic storm that disrupts the controls, or when you wish to perform a hard stop or pull a high-G turn.
Technology: Your Intelligence (Technology) check measures your ability to understand the inner workings of technological devices. Most devices are powered by some form of magic, but plenty of intricate design goes into channeling that magic into useful effects. Use this skill to understand unfamiliar or complex technology or to modify or repair devices. The GM may call for an Intelligence (Technology) check when you attempt to modify a blaster, repair your ship's {@item shield generator|darkmatter}, disable a rogue android, or sabotage an arcane terminal.

trait.name: Amorphous Form (Air)
entries: The elemental can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

trait.name: Illumination (Fire)
entries: Rumble sheds bright light in a 10-foot radius and dim light for an additional 10 feet.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) piercing damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 13}).

action.name: Ignite
entries: Flames burst out of Rumble's body each creature within 5 feet of him must makes a {@dc 13} dexterity check. A target takes {@damage 2d6} fire damage on a failed save and half as much on a successful one.

bonus.name: Burst of Speed
entries: After taking the dash action, rumble can use a bonus action to dash a second time.

bonus.name: Change Form
entries: Rumble can switch between its fire or air form as a bonus action.

trait.name: Dead Eye (3/Day)
entries: As a bonus action, the archer can add {@dice 1d10} to its next attack roll with a ranged weapon.
A creature hit by this attack always receive a fatal wound.

trait.name: Fatal Wound
entries: Whenever archer hits a creature, that is not a construct or undead, with a ranged weapon attack, the target must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or receive a fatal wound.
At the start of each of the targets turns it takes {@damage 1d6} piercing damage for each fatal wound it has.
Any creature can take an action to stanch the wounds with a successful {@dc 13} Wisdom (Medicine) check or using a healer's kit. The wounds also closes if the target receives magical healing.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The archer makes two attacks with its longbow.

action.name: Shortsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Longbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 7} to hit, range 150/600 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) piercing damage.

resist.note: (granted by the blast scepter, see "Special Equipment" below)

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: Unnubaris is a 20th-level spellcaster. His spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 24}, {@hit 14} to hit with spell attacks). He can cast {@spell disguise self} and {@spell invisibility} at will. He can cast {@spell fly} and {@spell lightning bolt} once each without expending a spell slot, but can't do so again until he finishes a short or long rest. Unnubaris has the following wizard spells prepared:

trait.name: Special Equipment
entries: Unnubaris wears a robe of eyes that lets him see in all directions, gives him darkvision out to a range of 120 feet, grants advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sight, and allows him to see {@condition invisible} creatures and objects, as well as into the Ethereal Plane, out to a range of 120 feet.

Unnubaris wields a blast scepter (a very rare magic item that requires attunement). It can be used as an arcane focus. Whoever is attuned to the blast scepter gains resistance to fire and lightning damage and can, as an action, use it to cast thunderwave as a 4th-level spell (save {@dc 16}) without expending a spell slot.
Unnubaris also wears a horned ring (a very rare magic item that requires attunement), which allows an attuned wearer to ignore Undermountain's magical restrictions (see \"Alterations to Magic\").

trait.name: Arcane Recovery (1/Day)
entries: When he finishes a short rest, Unnubaris recovers all his spell slots of 5th level and lower.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If Unnubaris fails a saving throw, he can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Rejuvenation
entries: If Unnubaris dies in Undermountain, he revives after {@dice 1d10} days, with all his hit points and any missing body parts restored. His new body appears in a random safe location in Undermountain.

action.name: Blast Scepter
entries: Unnubaris uses his blast scepter to cast thunderwave as a 4th-level spell. Each creature in a 15-foot cube originating from him must make a {@dc 16} Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes {@damage 5d8} thunder damage and is pushed 10 feet away. On a successful save, the creature takes half as much damage and isn't pushed

legendary.name: Cast Spell
entries: Unnubaris casts a spell of 3rd level or lower.

legendary.name: Spell Ward (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Unnubaris expends a spell slot of 4th level or lower and gains 5 temporary hit points per level of the slot.

trait.name: Detect Invisibility
entries: Within 60 feet of Grunt, magical invisibility fails to conceal anything from the Grunt's sight.

trait.name: Keen Smell
entries: Grunt has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on smell.

trait.name: Poison Sense
entries: Grunt can detect whether a substance is poisonous by taste, touch, or smell.

trait.name: Familiar
entries: With the DM's permission, a person who casts the find familiar spell can choose to conjure Grunt.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 0} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}1 slashing damage.

Lizards really, but legends grow. I am not sure, truth be told, what to believe or not believe when it comes to dwarven lap dragons. Some dwarven legends hold that millenia ago, dwarves somehow managed to 'domesticate' true dragons. How this was done is never truly explained by these fanciful tales, but suffice it to say it supposedly involved the stealing of many dragon eggs, proper incubation, followed by intense training, magical shrinkage and selective breeding. Other, more sober dwarves will tell you that lap-dragons are merely a kind of underground lizard, as related to true dragons, as mice are to eagles. Regardless of their unknown origins, lap-dragons can often be found in the homes of affluent dwarves.They are aptly named, as they view a dwarven lap, as a true dragon might view its lair; solid, comforting, and warm. In appearance, well, to these untrained eyes, they look like rat-sized lizards, yet these creatures have several unique abilities as well, perhaps lending some credence to their legends. Lap-Dragons can breathe forth noxious fumes, that dwarves seem immune to, yet I found unbearable. Let me also not neglect to mention that they are highly intelligent and mischievous, when not entombed in their master's laps having their emerald-green scales scratched. They also possess a peculiar capacity for judging character and intent! Often a dwarf will either welcome or send away a guest, depending on the hisses and scratchings of their lap-dragons, when brought in front of the individual. I would have to spend many more years, to truly explain the ecology of these reptiles, but know that they exist! I would welcome any naturalist's opinions on the matter.

monster.name: Felstalker
languages: understands Abyssal but can't speak it

trait.name: Mana Seeker
entries: The Felstalker has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks to detect creatures with any form of spellcasting.

trait.name: Pack Tactics
entries: The felstalker has advantage on an attack roll against a creature if at least one of the felstalker's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

trait.name: Mana Empowerment
entries: While the felstalker has temporary hit points from using its devour magic, it has advantage on attack rolls and deals an extra  {@damage 4d6} necrotic damage on its shadow bite, instead of {@damage 2d6}.

action.name: Shadow Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) piercing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) necrotic damage.

action.name: Empowered Shadow Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) piercing damage plus 14 ({@damage 4d6}) necrotic damage.

action.name: Devour Magic {@recharge 6}
entries: The felstalker inhales draining magic in a 15-foot cone.
All 3rd level spell in effect in the area ends and the felstalker gains 5 temporary hit points for each effect that was dispelled.

reaction.name: Spell Lock (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: When the felstalker sees a creature within 60 feet casting a spell a it can use its reaction to interrupt the process of casting the spell. If the spell is of 3rd level or lower it fails.

monster.name: Fel Armor

resist.note: from nonmagical attacks that aren't adamantine

languages: understands the languages of its creator but can't speak

spellcasting.name: Artificial Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Armor has some spells stored it can release the spell's energy (spell save {@dc 15}, {@hit 7}). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material or verbal components:

trait.name: Spell Immunity
entries: The Armor is immune to three spells chosen by its creator. Typical immunities include {@spell hunger of hadar}, {@spell heat metal}, and {@spell shatter}.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The armor has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Fel Core
entries: The Armor is powered by a core. If the armor is hit by a critical attack or once it reaches half its hit point maximum the core becomes exposed.
The core is an object with 30 hit points, AC 20 and resistance to all damage. If the core is destroyed the armor loses its magic resistance, spell immunity immidiately.
After {@dice 1d4+1} turns without its core the armor's hit points drops to 0.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The armor makes two attacks, or it can make one attack and cast a spell.

action.name: Greatsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 3d10 + 4}) slashing damage.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) bludgeoning damage.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: Unnubaris is a 20th-level spellcaster. His spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 20}, {@hit 10} to hit with spell attacks). He can cast {@spell burning hands} and {@spell invisibility} at will. Unnubaris has the following wizard spells prepared:

trait.name: Cunning Action
entries: On each of its turns, the rogue can use a bonus action to take the Dash, Disengage, or Hide action.

trait.name: Evasion
entries: If the rogue is subjected to an effect that allows it to make a Dexterity saving throw to take only half damage, the rogue instead takes no damage if it succeeds on the saving throw, and only half damage if it fails.

trait.name: Sneak Attack (1/Turn)
entries: The rogue deals an extra 14 ({@damage 4d6}) damage when it hits a target with a weapon attack and has advantage on the attack roll, or when the target is within 5 feet of an ally of the rogue that isn't incapacitated and the rogue doesn't have disadvantage on the attack roll.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The rogue makes two attacks with its Soul Knives or Rend Mind if available. It can use one of the attacks to use Psychic Teleportation once.

action.name: Soul Knives
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 60 ft., one target. {@h} 10 ({@damage 2d4 + 5}) psychic damage.

action.name: Rend Mind {@recharge 6}
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 60 ft., one target. {@h} 10 ({@damage 2d4 + 5}) psychic damage and the target must succeed on a {@dc 16} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition stunned} for 1 minute. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns.

action.name: Psychic Teleportation
entries: The rogue throws its soul knife at an unoccupied space it can see up to 60 feet away then teleports to that space picking up the knife.

action.name: Psychic Veil
entries: The rogue magically becomes {@condition invisible}, along with anything it is wearing or carrying for 1 hour or until it dismisses this effect (no action required). This invisibility ends early immediately after it deals damage to a creature or force a creature to make a saving throw.

bonus.name: Blade Parry
entries: As a bonus action you can project your blades and prepare them to parry attacks. You gain a +2 bonus to AC until the start of your next turn or until you are {@condition incapacitated}.

bonus.name: Blade Flurry
entries: After taking the attack action the rogue can make two additional attacks as a bonus action.

reaction.name: Uncanny Dodge
entries: The rogue halves the damage that it takes from an attack that hits it. The rogue must be able to see the attacker.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The ranger's innate spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 15}. It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Archer's Eye (3/Day)
entries: As a bonus action, the ranger can add {@dice 1d10} to its next attack or damage roll with a longbow or shortbow.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The ranger makes two attacks with its longbow.

action.name: Shortsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d6 + 5}) piercing damage.

action.name: Longbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 7} to hit, range 150/600 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d8 + 5}) piercing damage.

trait.name: Brave
entries: The spear thrower has advantage on saving throws against being {@condition frightened}.

trait.name: Brute
entries: A melee weapon deals one extra die of its damage when the spear thrower hits with it.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Spear Thrower makes two attacks.

action.name: Spear
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft. and range 30/120 ft., one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 2d12 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Shield Bash
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d4 + 4}) bludgeoning damage. If the target is a Medium or smaller creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

reaction.name: Parry
entries: The Spear Thrower adds 3 to its AC against one melee attack that would hit it. To do so, the gladiator must see the attacker and be wielding a melee weapon.

trait.name: Keen Sight and Smell
entries: The owlbear has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight or smell.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The owlbear makes two attacks: one with its beak and one with its claws.

action.name: Beak
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}10 ({@damage 1d10 + 5}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d8 + 5}) slashing damage.

An owlbear's screech echoes through dark valleys and benighted forests, piercing the quiet night to announce the death of its prey. Feathers cover the thick, shaggy coat of its bearlike body, and the limpid pupils of its great round eyes stare furiously from its owlish head.

entries.name: Deadly Ferocity
entries: The owlbear's reputation for ferocity, aggression, stubbornness, and sheer ill temper makes it one of the most feared predators of the wild. There is little, if anything, that a hungry owlbear fears. Even monsters that outmatch an owlbear in size and strength avoid tangling with it, for this creature cares nothing about a foe's superior strength as it attacks without provocation.

entries.name: Consummate Predators
entries: An owlbear emerges from its den around sunset and hunts into the darkest hours of the night, hooting or screeching to declare its territory, to search for a mate, or to flush prey into its hunting grounds. These are typically forests familiar to the owlbear, and dense enough to limit its quarry's escape routes.

An owlbear makes its den in a cave or ruin littered with the bones of its prey. It drags partially devoured kills back to its den, storing portions of the carcass among the surrounding rocks, bushes, and trees. The scent of blood and rotting flesh hangs heavy near an owlbear's lair, attracting scavengers and thus luring more prey.

Owlbears hunt alone or in mated pairs. If quarry is plentiful, a family of owlbears might remain together for longer than is required to rear offspring. Otherwise, they part ways as soon as the young are ready to hunt.

entries.name: Savage Companions
entries: Although they are more intelligent than most animals, owlbears are difficult to tame. However, with enough time, food, and luck, an intelligent creature can train an owlbear to recognize it as a master, making it an unflinching guard or a fast and hardy mount. People of remote frontier settlements have even succeeded at racing owlbears, but spectators bet as often on which owlbear will attack its handler as they do on which will reach the finish line first.

Elven communities encourage owlbears to den beneath their treetop villages, using the beasts as a natural defense during the night. Hobgoblins favor owlbears as war beasts, and hill giants and frost giants sometimes keep owlbears as pets. A starved owlbear might show up in a gladiatorial arena, ruthlessly eviscerating and devouring its foes before a bloodthirsty audience.

entries.name: Owlbear Origins
entries: Scholars have long debated the origins of the owlbear. The most common theory is that a demented wizard created the first specimen by crossing a giant owl with a bear. However, venerable elves claim to have known these creatures for thousands of years, and some fey insist that owlbears have always existed in the Feywild.

trait.name: Amorphous Form (Air)
entries: The elemental can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

trait.name: Heated Body (fire)
entries: A creature that touches rumble or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it takes 3 ({@dice 1d6}) fire damage.

trait.name: Illumination (fire)
entries: Rumble sheds bright light in a 10-foot radius and dim light for an additional 10 feet.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d6 + 2}) piercing damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 13}).

bonus.name: Burst of Speed
entries: After taking the dash action, rumble can use a bonus action to dash a second time.

bonus.name: Change Form
entries: As a bonus action rumble can change its elemental form from Air to fire.

trait.name: Amorphous Form (Air)
entries: The elemental can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

trait.name: Illumination (Fire)
entries: Rumble sheds bright light in a 10-foot radius and dim light for an additional 10 feet.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) piercing damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 13}).

action.name: Ignite (Fire form Only)
entries: Flames burst out of Rumble's body each creature within 5 feet of him must makes a {@dc 13} dexterity check. A target takes {@damage 2d6} fire damage on a failed save and half as much on a successful one.

bonus.name: Burst of Speed
entries: After taking the dash action, rumble can use a bonus action to dash a second time.

bonus.name: Change Form
entries: Rumble can switch between its fire or air form as a bonus action.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting (1/Day)
headerEntries: The hunter can innately cast spells. Its innate spellcasting ability is Intelligence.

trait.name: Blood Curse of Binding (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: As a bonus action, the hunter targets one creature it can see within 30 feet of it. The target must succeed on a {@dc 17} Strength saving throw or have its speed reduced to 0 and be unable to take reactions. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

trait.name: Blood Frenzy
entries: The hunter has advantage on melee attack rolls against any creature that doesn't have all its hit points.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The hunter has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Brand of Castigation (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: When the hunter hits a creature with a weapon attack he can brand the target.
A branded creature reverts to its true form and it must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw whenever it tries to alter its form, teleport or leave its current plane.
Additionally the creature can't take the Dash action.

trait.name: Mutagens
entries: The hunter regains 10 hit points at the start of its turn if it has at least 1 hit point.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The hunter makes three attacks with a weapon or use its Fire Bolt thrice.

action.name: Flametongue
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) slashing damage plus 14 ({@damage 4d6}) fire damage.

action.name: Fire Bolt
entries: {@atk rs} {@hit 10} to hit, range 120 feet, one target. {@h}22 ({@damage 4d10}) fire damage.

reaction.name: Ring of Evasion (3/day)
entries: If the hunter fails a dexterity saving throw, it can use its reaction to succeed instead.

spellcasting.name: Constant Effects
headerEntries: The mage is always under the effect of one of the following spells, requiring no concentration. At the start of its turn the mage can change which spell affects him or reactivate it if it was dispelled (no action required).

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The mage is a 20th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 21} , {@hit 13} to hit with spell attacks). The mage has the following wizard spells prepared:

trait.name: Transmuter's Stone
entries: Once a day the mage can use its action to consume the energy reserves of his transmuter's stone to create one of the following effects:
{@b Panacea} The mage remove all curses, diseases, and poisons affecting a creature that it touches with the transmuter's stone. The creature also regains all its hit points.
{@b Restore Life} The mage can cast {@spell raise dead} spell on a creature it touches with the transmuter's stone, without expending a spell slot or having the spell prepared.

{@b Restore Youth} The mage touches a willing creature with the stone, and that creature's apparent age is reduced by {@dice 3d10} years, to a minimum of 13 years. This effect doesn't extend the creature's lifespan.

trait.name: Master of Transmutation
entries: The mage can't be affected by spells the school of transmutation unless it wishes to be. It has advantage on saving throws against all other spells and magical effects.
Additionaly any spell of 2nd level or lower from the transmutation school cast by the mage do not require concentration and has its duration increased to 1 hour (if not already).

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the mage fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

bonus.name: Enhanced Support
entries: Whenever the mage casts {@spell polymorph}, {@spell mass polymorph|XGE} or {@spell true polymorph}, {@spell animate objects} it can affect the target with a 1st or 2nd level spell as a bonus action.

reaction.name: Elemental Rebuke
entries: When the mage is hit by an attack it can use its reaction to cast a Investiture Spell, requiring no concentration. The spell lasts until the start of his next turn.
{@spell Investiture of flame|XGE}
{@spell Investiture of ice|XGE}
{@spell Investiture of stone|XGE}
{@spell Investiture of wind|XGE}

legendary.name: Higher Casting(2)
entries: The mage casts a spell.

legendary.name: Lesser Casting
entries: The mage casts a spell of 3rd level or lower.

legendary.name: Move
entries: The mage move up to its speed.

legendary.name: Use item
entries: The mage uses an item.

trait.name: Axiomatic Mind
entries: The duodrone can't be compelled to act in a manner contrary to its nature or its instructions.

trait.name: Disintegration
entries: If the duodrone dies, its body disintegrates into dust, leaving behind its weapons and anything else it was carrying.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The duodrone makes two fist attacks or two javelin attacks.

action.name: Fist
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 2} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}2 ({@damage 1d4}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Javelin
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 30/120 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d6 + 1}) piercing damage.

variant.name: Rogue Modrons
entries: A modron unit sometimes becomes defective, either through natural decay or exposure to chaotic forces. Rogue modrons don't act in accordance with Primus's wishes and directives, breaking laws, disobeying orders, and even engaging in violence. Other modrons hunt down such rogues.
A rogue modron loses the Axiomatic Mind trait and can have any alignment other than lawful neutral. Otherwise, it has the same statistics as a regular modron of its rank.
The blocky duodrones supervise units of monodrones and can perform up to two tasks at a time.

entries.name: Modrons
entries: Modrons are beings of absolute law that adhere to a hive-like hierarchy. They inhabit the plane of Mechanus and tend its eternally revolving gears, their existence a clockwork routine of perfect order.

entries.name: Absolute Law and Order
entries: Under the direction of their leader, Primus, modrons increase order in the multiverse in accordance with laws beyond the comprehension of mortal minds. Their own minds are networked in a hierarchal pyramid, in which each modron receives commands from superiors and delegates orders to underlings. A modron carries out commands with total obedience, utmost efficiency, and an absence of morality or ego. Modrons have no sense of self beyond what is necessary to fulfill their duties. They exist as a unified collective, divided by ranks, yet they always refer to themselves collectively. To a modron, there is no "I," but only "we" or "us."
Variant: Rogue Modrons

A modron unit sometimes becomes defective, either through natural decay or exposure to chaotic forces. Rogue modrons don't act in accordance with Primus's wishes and directives, breaking laws, disobeying orders, and even engaging in violence. Other modrons hunt down such rogues.
A rogue modron loses the Axiomatic Mind trait and can have any alignment other than lawful neutral. Otherwise, it has the same statistics as a regular modron of its rank.

entries.name: Absolute Hierarchy
entries: Modrons communicate only with their own rank and the ranks immediately above and below them. Modrons more than one rank away are either too advanced or too simple to understand.

entries.name: Cogs of the Great Machine
entries: If a modron is destroyed, its remains disintegrate. A replacement from the next lowest rank then transforms in a flash of light, gaining the physical form of its new rank. The promoted modron is replaced by one of its underlings in the same manner, all the way to the lowest levels of the hierarchy. There, a new modron is created by Primus, with a steady stream of monodrones leaving the Great Modron Cathedral on Mechanus as a result.

entries.name: The Great Modron March
entries: When the gears of Mechanus complete seventeen cycles once every 289 years, Primus sends a vast army of modrons across the Outer Planes, ostensibly on a reconnaissance mission. The march is long and dangerous, and only a small number of modrons returns to Mechanus.

trait.name: Axiomatic Mind
entries: The monodrone can't be compelled to act in a manner contrary to its nature or its instructions.

trait.name: Disintegration
entries: If the monodrone dies, its body disintegrates into dust, leaving behind its weapons and anything else it was carrying.

action.name: Dagger
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d4 + 1}) piercing damage.

action.name: Javelin
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 2} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 30/120 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d6}) piercing damage.

action.name: Excavate {@recharge 6}
entries: A thin blue ray springs from the monodrone eyes toward a creature within 10 feet. A creature targeted by this ray must make a {@dc 14} Dexterity saving throw or take {@damage 10d6 + 40} force damage.

trait.name: Axiomatic Mind
entries: The pentadrone can't be compelled to act in a manner contrary to its nature or its instructions.

trait.name: Disintegration
entries: If the pentadrone dies, its body disintegrates into dust, leaving behind its weapons and anything else it was carrying.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The pentadrone makes five arm attacks.

action.name: Arm
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Paralysis Gas {@recharge 5}
entries: The pentadrone exhales a 30-foot cone of gas. Each creature in that area must succeed on a {@dc 11} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition paralyzed} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

variant.name: Rogue Modrons
entries: A modron unit sometimes becomes defective, either through natural decay or exposure to chaotic forces. Rogue modrons don't act in accordance with Primus's wishes and directives, breaking laws, disobeying orders, and even engaging in violence. Other modrons hunt down such rogues.
A rogue modron loses the Axiomatic Mind trait and can have any alignment other than lawful neutral. Otherwise, it has the same statistics as a regular modron of its rank.
Pentadrones oversee Mechanus's worker populace and can improvise in response to new situations.

entries.name: Modrons
entries: Modrons are beings of absolute law that adhere to a hive-like hierarchy. They inhabit the plane of Mechanus and tend its eternally revolving gears, their existence a clockwork routine of perfect order.

entries.name: Absolute Law and Order
entries: Under the direction of their leader, Primus, modrons increase order in the multiverse in accordance with laws beyond the comprehension of mortal minds. Their own minds are networked in a hierarchal pyramid, in which each modron receives commands from superiors and delegates orders to underlings. A modron carries out commands with total obedience, utmost efficiency, and an absence of morality or ego. Modrons have no sense of self beyond what is necessary to fulfill their duties. They exist as a unified collective, divided by ranks, yet they always refer to themselves collectively. To a modron, there is no "I," but only "we" or "us."
Variant: Rogue Modrons

A modron unit sometimes becomes defective, either through natural decay or exposure to chaotic forces. Rogue modrons don't act in accordance with Primus's wishes and directives, breaking laws, disobeying orders, and even engaging in violence. Other modrons hunt down such rogues.
A rogue modron loses the Axiomatic Mind trait and can have any alignment other than lawful neutral. Otherwise, it has the same statistics as a regular modron of its rank.

entries.name: Absolute Hierarchy
entries: Modrons communicate only with their own rank and the ranks immediately above and below them. Modrons more than one rank away are either too advanced or too simple to understand.

entries.name: Cogs of the Great Machine
entries: If a modron is destroyed, its remains disintegrate. A replacement from the next lowest rank then transforms in a flash of light, gaining the physical form of its new rank. The promoted modron is replaced by one of its underlings in the same manner, all the way to the lowest levels of the hierarchy. There, a new modron is created by Primus, with a steady stream of monodrones leaving the Great Modron Cathedral on Mechanus as a result.

entries.name: The Great Modron March
entries: When the gears of Mechanus complete seventeen cycles once every 289 years, Primus sends a vast army of modrons across the Outer Planes, ostensibly on a reconnaissance mission. The march is long and dangerous, and only a small number of modrons returns to Mechanus.

trait.name: Rust Metal
entries: Any nonmagical weapon made of metal that hits the rust dragon corrodes. After dealing damage, the weapon takes a permanent and cumulative 1 penalty to damage rolls. If its penalty drops to 5, the weapon is destroyed. Nonmagical ammunition made of metal that hits the rust dragon is destroyed after dealing damage.
The rust dragon can eat through 2-inch-thick, nonmagical metal in 1 round.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The rust dragon makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its claws.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 2d10 + 6}) piercing damage plus ({@damage 2d6}) acid damage.

Additionally, if the creature is using a nonmagical metal armor or shield it takes a cumulative -1 penalty to the AC. If the armor is reduced below 10 AC or the shield drops to a bonus of +0 it is destroyed.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d6 + 6}) slashing damage plus {@damage 2d6} acid damage.

action.name: Rust Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: The rust dragon exhales a corrosive acid in a 100-foot line. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 17} Dexterity saving throw, taking ({@damage 14d6}) acid damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

Additionally, if the creature is using a nonmagical metal armor or shield it takes a cumulative -1 penalty to the AC. If the armor is reduced below 10 AC or the shield drops to a bonus of +0 it is destroyed.

trait.name: Charge
entries: If the black ice golem moves at least 15 feet straight toward a target and then hits it with its tusks on the same turn, the target takes an extra {@damage 1d12} bludgeoning damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

trait.name: Transmuted
entries: The Golem is under the effect of the following spells:
{@spell expeditious retreat}
{@spell longstrider}
{@spell enhance ability} Bull's Strength
{@spell magic weapon}

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 2d12 + 5}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Running Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}24 ({@damage 3d12 + 5}) bludgeoning damage.

monster.name: Secret Keeper
languages: the languages it knew in life

trait.name: Incorporeal Movement
entries: The allip can move through other creatures and objects as if they were difficult terrain. It takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) force damage if it ends its turn inside an object.

action.name: Maddening Touch
entries: {@atk ms} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 4d6 + 3}) psychic damage.

action.name: Whispers of Madness
entries: The allip chooses up to three creatures it can see within 60 feet of it. Each target must succeed on a {@dc 16} Wisdom saving throw, or it takes 7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) psychic damage and must use its reaction to make a melee weapon attack against one creature of the allip's choice that the allip can see. Constructs and undead are immune to this effect.

action.name: Howling Babble {@recharge}
entries: Each creature within 30 feet of the allip that can hear it must make a {@dc 16} Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, a target takes 12 ({@damage 2d8 + 3}) psychic damage, and it is {@condition stunned} until the end of its next turn. On a successful save, it takes half as much damage and isn't {@condition stunned}. Constructs and undead are immune to this effect.

entries.name: Allip
entries: When a mind uncovers a secret that a powerful being has protected with a mighty curse, the result is often the emergence of an allip. Secrets protected in this manner range in scope from a demon lord's true name to the hidden truths of the cosmic order. The allip acquires the secret, but the curse annihilates its body and leaves behind a spectral creature composed of fragments from the victim's psyche and overwhelming psychic agony.

entries.name: Blasphemous Secrets
entries: Every allip is wracked with a horrifying insight that torments what remains of its mind. In the presence of other creatures, an allip seeks to relieve this burden by sharing its secret. The creature can impart only a shard of the knowledge that doomed it, but that piece is enough to wrack the recipient with temporary madness.

The survivors of an allip's attack are sometimes left with a compulsion to learn more about what spawned this monstrosity. Strange phrases echo through their minds, and weird visions occupy their dreams. The sense that some colossal truth sits just outside their recall plagues them for days, months, and sometimes years after their fateful encounter.

entries.name: Undead Nature
entries: An allip doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

entries.name: Insidious Lore
entries: An allip might attempt to share its lore to escape its curse and enter the afterlife. It can transfer knowledge from its mind by guiding another creature to write down what it knows. This process takes days or possibly weeks. An allip can accomplish this task by lurking in the study or workplace of a scholar. If the allip remains hidden, its victim is gradually overcome by manic energy. A scholar, driven by sudden insights to work night and day, produces reams of text with little memory of exactly what the documents contain. If the allip succeeds, it passes from the worldand its terrible secret hides somewhere in the scholar's text, waiting to be discovered by its next victim.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The follower is a 14th-level spellcaster. His spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 16}, {@hit 8} to hit with spell attacks). Zindar knows the following sorcerer spells:

trait.name: Dragon Wings
entries: As a bonus action on his turn, Zindar can sprout a pair of dragon wings from his back, gaining a flying speed of 30 feet until he dismisses them as a bonus action.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The follower makes two claw attacks and use his breath weapon, it can replace a claw attack with a spell.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d6 + 5}) slashing damage plus 14 ({@damage 4d6}) fire.

action.name: Breath Weapon {@recharge 5}
entries: Zindar uses one of the following options:

action.name: Fire Breath
entries: The follower exhales fire in a 15-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 16} Dexterity saving throw, taking 22 ({@damage 4d10}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

action.name: Weakening Breath
entries: Zindar exhales gas in a 15-foot cone. Each creature in that area must succeed on a {@dc 16} Strength saving throw or have disadvantage on Strength-based attack rolls, Strength checks, and Strength saving throws for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The moray makes two attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}29 ({@damage 4d10 + 7}) piercing damage. The target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 20}), and the target is {@condition restrained} until this grapple ends.

action.name: Swallow
entries: The moray makes one bite attack against a Medium or smaller target it is grappling. If the attack hits, the target is also swallowed, and the grapple ends. While swallowed, the target is {@condition blinded} and {@condition restrained}, it has total cover against attacks and other effects outside the moray, it takes 24 ({@damage 7d6}) cold damage and have its maximum Constitution reduced by 1 at the start of each of the moray's turns. If the swallowed creature's Constitution is reduced to  0 it dies. A moray can have only one creature swallowed at a time.

If the moray takes 30 damage or more on a single turn from the swallowed creature, the moray must succeed on a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw at the end of that turn or regurgitate the creature, which falls {@condition prone} in a space within 10 feet of the moray. If the moray dies, a swallowed creature is no longer {@condition restrained} by it and can escape from the corpse by using 15 feet of movement, exiting {@condition prone}.

action.name: Cold Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: The moray exhales chill wind in a 60-foot cone.  Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 20} Constitution saving throw, taking 82 ({@damage 15d10}) cold damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The octopus can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Freedom of Movement
entries: The octopus ignores difficult terrain, and magical effects can't reduce its speed or cause it to be {@condition restrained}. It can spend 5 feet of movement to escape from nonmagical restraints or being {@condition grappled}.

trait.name: Legendary Charge
entries: If the octopus don't use up all of its legendary actions on a round, it reduces the value required on its next recharge roll by 1 for each action unspent.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The octopus makes three tentacle attacks, each of which it can replace with a use of Fling or Pressurized Jet (if available).

action.name: Tentacle
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 12} to hit, reach 20 ft., one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 3d6 + 7}) bludgeoning damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 20}). Until the grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}. The octopus has eight tentacles, each of which can grapple one target.

action.name: Fling
entries: One Medium or smaller object held or creature {@condition grappled} by the octopus is thrown up to 40 feet in a choosen direction and knocked {@condition prone}. If a thrown target strikes a solid surface, the target takes 3 ({@damage 1d6}) bludgeoning damage for every 10 feet it was thrown. If the target is thrown at another creature, that creature must succeed on a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw or take the same damage and be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Pressurized Jet {@recharge 5}
entries: The octopus shoots pressurized water jet at a target it can see within 120 feet. The target must make a {@dc 18} Dexterity saving throw, taking 55 ({@damage 10d10}) piercing damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

legendary.name: Tentacle Attack (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The octopus makes one tentacle attack.

legendary.name: Fling
entries: The kraken uses Fling.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The frostmage's spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 19}, {@hit 11} to hit). The frostmage can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

1e: {@spell summon greater demon|XGE} (up to CR 9, it's obedient)

trait.name: Piercing Gold
entries: The frostmage's attacks ignore cold resistance.
Additionally when the frostmage hits a creature that is {@condition restrained} by Deepfreeze, the creature has vulnerability to cold damage.

trait.name: Deepfreeze {@recharge 5}
entries: When the frostmage hits a creature with an attack that deals cold damage it can use its bonus action to freeze the target in place,  the target must make a {@dc 19} Constitution saving throw. On a faild save it takes {@damage 4d8} cold damage and becomes {@condition restrained}, on successful save it only takes half the damage.
A creature can spend its action to make a {@dc 18} Strength saving throw to try to break free from the ice.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The frostmage makes two coldfist attacks.

action.name: Coldfist
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}25 ({@damage 1d12 + 6}) bludgeoning damage plus ({@damage 2d12}) cold damage.

action.name: Frostball
entries: {@atk rs} {@hit 11} to hit, range 240 ft., one target. {@h}28 ({@damage 4d10 + 6}) cold damage.
"type": "entries",
"entries": [
"type": "entries",
"entries": [

"Gigantic reavers from the freezing lands beyond civilization, frost giants are fierce, hardy warriors that survive on the spoils of their raids and pillaging. They respect only brute strength and skill in battle, demonstrating both with their scars and the grisly trophies they take from their enemies.",
"type": "entries",
"name": "Hearts of Ice",
"entries": [
"Frost giants are creatures of ice and snow. Their hair and beards are pale white or light blue, matted with frost and clattering with icicles. Their flesh is as blue as glacial ice.",

"Frost giants dwell in high peaks and glacial rifts where the sun hides its golden head by winter. Crops don't grow in their frozen homelands, and they keep little livestock beyond what they capture in their raids against civilized lands. They hunt the wild game of the tundra and mountains but don't cook it, since meat from a fresh kill tastes sufficiently hot to their palate."
"type": "entries",
"name": "Reavers of the Storm",
"entries": [

"The war horns of the frost giants howl as they march from their ice fortresses and glacial rifts amid the howling blizzard. When that storm clears, villages and steadings lay in ruins, ravens descending to feed on the corpses of any creatures foolish or unlucky enough to stand in the giants' path.",

"Inns and taverns suffer the brunt of the damage, their cellars gutted and their casks of ale and mead gone. Smithies are likewise toppled, their iron and steel claimed. Curiously undisturbed are the houses of moneylenders and wealthy citizens, for the reavers have little use for coins or baubles. Frost giants prize gems and jewelry large enough to be worn and noticed. However, even those treasures are most often saved for trading opportunities with other giants more adept at crafting metal weapons and armor."
"type": "entries",
"name": "Rulers by Might",
"entries": [

"Frost giants respect brute strength above all else, and a frost giant's place in the ordning depends on evidence of physical might, such as superior musculature, scars from battles of renown, or trophies fashioned from the bodies of slain enemies. Tasks such as hunting, childrearing, and crafting are given to giants based on their physical strength and hardiness.",

"When frost giants of different clans meet and their status is unclear, they wrestle for dominance. Such meetings might resemble festivals where giants cheer on their champions, making bold boasts and challenges. At other times, the informal ceremony can become a chaotic free-for-all where both clans rush into a melee that fells trees, shatters the ice on frozen lakes, and causes avalanches on the snowy mountainsides."
"type": "entries",
"name": "Make War, Not Goods",
"entries": [

"Though frost giants consider the menial crafting of goods beneath them, carving and leatherwork are valued skills. They make their clothing from the skins and bones of beasts, and carve bone or ivory into jewelry and the handles of weapons and tools. They reuse the weapons and armor of their smaller foes, stringing shields into scale armor and lashing sword blades to wooden hafts to make giant-sized spears. The greatest battle trophies come from conquered dragons, and the greatest frost giant jarls wear armor of dragon scales or wield picks and mauls made of a dragon's teeth or claws."
"type": "section",
"name": "Giants",
"entries": [

"Ancient empires once cast long shadows over a world that quaked beneath the giants' feet. In those lost days, these towering figures were dragon slayers, dreamers, crafters, and kings, but their kind fell from glory long ago. However, even divided among secluded clans scattered throughout the world, the giants maintain the customs and traditions of old.",
"name": "Old as Legend",
"type": "entries",
"entries": [

"In remote regions of the world, the last remaining plinths, monoliths, and statues of the great giant empires bow their heads in desolate obscurity. Where once those empires sprawled across all lands, now the giants dwell in isolated tribes and clans.",

"Giants are almost as old as dragons, which were still young when the giants' heavy feet first shook the foundations of the world. As they spread across new lands, giants and dragons fought bitter generational wars that nearly brought both sides low. No living giant remembers what started the conflict, but myths and tales of their race's glorious dawn are still sung in their steadings and holdfasts, vilifying the primeval wyrms. Giants and dragons continue to harbor grudges against one another, and it is seldom that they will meet or occupy the same area without a fight."
"type": "entries",
"name": "The Ordning",
"entries": [

"Each of the main giant races-the cloud, fire, frost, hill, stone, and storm giants-are related by common elements of history, religion, and culture. They view one another as kindred, keeping any inherent animosity over territory and ambition to a minimum.",

"Giants belong to a caste structure called the ordning. Based on social class and highly organized, the ordning assigns a social rank to each giant. By understanding its place in the ordning, a giant knows which other giants are inferior or superior to it, since no two giants are equal. Each of the giant races analyzes a different combination of skills or qualities to determine the ordning. Giants make excelling in these qualities the purpose of their lives.",

"At the highest level of the ordning, the races of the giants are also ranked according to status. Storm giants are the highest in the ordning, followed by cloud giants, fire giants, frost giants, stone giants, hill giants, and finally giant kin such as fomorians, ettins, and ogres.",

"Regardless of a giant's rank among its own race, the chief of a hill giant tribe is inferior to the most common of stone giants. The lowest ranked giant of any type is superior to the highest ranked giant of an inferior type. It isn't considered evil to disrespect or even betray a giant of another type, merely rude."
"type": "inset",
"name": "Giant Gods",
"entries": [

"When the giants' ancient empires fell, Annam, father of all giants, forsook his children and the world. He swore never to look upon either again until the giants had returned to their glory and reclaimed their birthright as rulers of the world. As a result, giants pray not to Annam but to his divine children, along with a host of hero-deities and godly villains that make up the giants' pantheon.",

"Chief among these gods are the children of Annam, whose sons represent each type of giant: Stronmaus for storm giants, Memnor for cloud giants, Skoraeus Stonebones for stone giants, Thrym for frost giants, Surtur for fire giants, and Grolantor for hill giants. Not all giants automatically revere their kind's primary deity, however. Many good cloud giants refuse to worship the deceitful Memnor, and a storm giant dwelling in the icy mountains of the north might pay more homage to Thrym than Stronmaus. Other giants feel a stronger connection to Annam's daughters, who include Hiatea, the huntress and home warden; Iallanis, goddess of love and peace; and Diancastra, an impetuous and arrogant trickster.",

"Some giants abandon their own gods and fall prey to demon cults, paying homage to Baphomet or Kostchtchie. To worship them or any other non-giant deity is a great sin against the ordning, and almost certain to make a giant an outcast."

trait.name: Regeneration
entries: The giant regains 10 hit points at the start of its turn. If the giant takes acid or fire damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of its next turn. The giant dies only if it starts its turn with 0 hit points and doesn't regenerate.

trait.name: Everlasting Fury
entries: The giant is always seething with rage. As long as the giant is not {@condition incapacitated} it is raging and gains the following benefits:
- The giant has advantage on Strength checks and Strength saving throws
- When it makes a melee weapon attack, the giant gains a +4 bonus to the damage roll.
- Ranged weapon attacks doesn't impose disadvantage if they are made using strength.
- The giant has resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage.

trait.name: Multiple Arms
entries: The giant has four extra arms giving it more leeway to interact with the environment. It can pick up or interact with up to four items on its turn requiring no action.
Additionaly when a creature provokes an opportunity attack it can grapple the target instead.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The giant makes four attacks with its Frost Handaxes.
It can forgo two handaxes attacks to use its Rock.

action.name: Frost Handaxe
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}24 ({@damage 3d8 + 11}) slashing damage while raging.

action.name: Frost Handaxe (Throw)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h}20 ({@damage 3d8 + 7}) slashing damage.

action.name: Rock
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 11} to hit, range 60/240 ft., one target. {@h}29 ({@damage 4d10 + 7}) bludgeoning damage.
"type": "entries",
"entries": [
"type": "entries",
"entries": [
"type": "entries",
"entries": [

"To hold its place or rise within the ordning, a frost giant must routinely face mighty foes in single combat. Some seek out magic that will aid them, but enchanted objects can be taken or lost. True greatness relies on personal prowess. Faced with this truth, a frost giant might seek a supernatural gift from Vaprak the Destroyer.",
"name": "Troll Eater",
"entries": [

" Frost giants mainly turn to Vaprak, a rapacious god of strength and hunger worshiped by ogres and trolls, out of desperation. Vaprak likes to tempt frost giants with dreams of glory followed by nightmares of bloody cannibalism. Those who don't shrink from such visions or report them to priests of Thrym receive more of the same. If a frost giant comes to relish these dreams and nightmares, as some do, Vaprak sets a troll upon a sacred quest to find the frost giant and meet it in secret. The troll offers up its own body to be devoured in Vaprak's name. Only the boldest and most determined frost giants can finish such a gory feast."
"type": "entries"
"name": "Vaprak's Blessing",
"entries": [

" After devouring the troll sent by Vaprak, bones and all, a frost giant becomes an everlasting one, gaining tremendous strength, an ill temper, and a troll's regenerative ability. With these gifts, the frost giant can swiftly claim the title of jarl and easily fend off rivals for decades. However, if the frost giant doesn't give enough honor to Vaprak or fails to heed Vaprak's visions, injuries the frost giant sustains heal wrong, often resulting in discolored skin, warty scars, and vestigial body parts, such as extra digits, limbs, and even extra heads. The touch of Vaprak can no longer be hidden then, and the everlasting one is either killed or exiled by its clan. Sometimes small communities of everlasting ones gather and even reproduce, passing the \"blessing\" and worship of Vaprak from one generation to the next."
"type": "entries"

trait.name: Aggressive
entries: As a bonus action, the hill giant can move up to its speed toward a hostile creature that it can see.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The giant makes two greatclub attacks.

action.name: Greatclub
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}30 ({@damage 5d8 + 8}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Rock
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 13} to hit, range 60/240 ft., one target. {@h}52 ({@damage 8d10 + 8}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The giant makes three flail attacks. It can exchange two flail attacks for a Cage Smash.

action.name: Cage Smash
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 20 ft., one target. {@h}24 ({@damage 3d10 + 8}) bludgeoning damage. Hit or miss, each creature within 10 feet of the target makes a {{@dc 20}} Dexterity Saving throw taking 36 ({@damage 8d8}) on a failed save or half as much on a successful one.

action.name: Rock
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 13} to hit, range 60/240 ft., one target. {@h}21 ({@damage 8d10 + 8}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Flail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 20 ft., one target. {@h}24 ({@damage 3d10 + 8}) bludgeoning damage.

bonus.name: Imprison
entries: As a bonus action the giant Imprison a medium or smaller creature {@condition grappled} by him into his Flail Cage.
While imprisoned a creature has total cover and cannot see outside of the cage.
A creature can attack the cage to destroy it, releasing the imprisoned creature. It has 20 AC, 100 hp, resistance to all damage and immunity to psychic damage.
Additionally an imprisoned creature always fail the saving throw against the Cage Smash attack.

reaction.name: Wild Swing
entries: When a creature within 20 feet of the Giant moves he can make a Fail attack against the creature.

trait.name: Aggressive
entries: As a bonus action, the hill giant can move up to its speed toward a hostile creature that it can see.

trait.name: Dumb Rage
entries: When the Giant is below its half hit point maximum it becomes enraged. It has advantage on attacks and ability checks using strength.
Additionaly when it hits a creature with its bite attack it is always a critical.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The giant makes three swords attacks. It can switch two sword attacks for a bite attack.

action.name: Sword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}30 ({@damage 5d8 + 8}) slashing damage.

action.name: Rock
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 13} to hit, range 60/240 ft., one target. {@h}52 ({@damage 8d10 + 8}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 8d10 + 8}) piercing damage. This attack has advantage against a {@condition grappled} creature.

trait.name: Cold Aura
entries: The ground in a 10-foot radius around the giant is icy and is difficult terrain for creatures other than the giant. The radius moves with the giant and lasts until he dismisses it (no action required) or become {@condition incapacitated}.

trait.name: Aggressive
entries: As a bonus action, the frost giant can move up to its speed toward a hostile creature that it can see.

trait.name: Icy Veins
entries: As a bonus action the giant cools down his blood hardening his muscles. The giant gains resistance to fire, bludgeoning, slashing and piercing damage but can't benefit from advantage on attack rolls. This effect lasts until the giant dismisses it with a bonus action.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The giant makes two greatsword attacks.

action.name: Greatsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}20 ({@damage 4d6 + 6}) slashing damage plus 14 ({@damage 4d6}) cold damage.

action.name: Ice Javelin
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 11} to hit, range 120/240 ft., one target. {@h}39 ({@damage 6d10 + 6}) cold damage and the target speed is halved.

Gigantic reavers from the freezing lands beyond civilization, frost giants are fierce, hardy warriors that survive on the spoils of their raids and pillaging. They respect only brute strength and skill in battle, demonstrating both with their scars and the grisly trophies they take from their enemies.

entries.name: Hearts of Ice
entries: Frost giants are creatures of ice and snow. Their hair and beards are pale white or light blue, matted with frost and clattering with icicles. Their flesh is as blue as glacial ice.

Frost giants dwell in high peaks and glacial rifts where the sun hides its golden head by winter. Crops don't grow in their frozen homelands, and they keep little livestock beyond what they capture in their raids against civilized lands. They hunt the wild game of the tundra and mountains but don't cook it, since meat from a fresh kill tastes sufficiently hot to their palate.

entries.name: Reavers of the Storm
entries: The war horns of the frost giants howl as they march from their ice fortresses and glacial rifts amid the howling blizzard. When that storm clears, villages and steadings lay in ruins, ravens descending to feed on the corpses of any creatures foolish or unlucky enough to stand in the giants' path.

Inns and taverns suffer the brunt of the damage, their cellars gutted and their casks of ale and mead gone. Smithies are likewise toppled, their iron and steel claimed. Curiously undisturbed are the houses of moneylenders and wealthy citizens, for the reavers have little use for coins or baubles. Frost giants prize gems and jewelry large enough to be worn and noticed. However, even those treasures are most often saved for trading opportunities with other giants more adept at crafting metal weapons and armor.

entries.name: Rulers by Might
entries: Frost giants respect brute strength above all else, and a frost giant's place in the ordning depends on evidence of physical might, such as superior musculature, scars from battles of renown, or trophies fashioned from the bodies of slain enemies. Tasks such as hunting, childrearing, and crafting are given to giants based on their physical strength and hardiness.

When frost giants of different clans meet and their status is unclear, they wrestle for dominance. Such meetings might resemble festivals where giants cheer on their champions, making bold boasts and challenges. At other times, the informal ceremony can become a chaotic free-for-all where both clans rush into a melee that fells trees, shatters the ice on frozen lakes, and causes avalanches on the snowy mountainsides.

entries.name: Make War, Not Goods
entries: Though frost giants consider the menial crafting of goods beneath them, carving and leatherwork are valued skills. They make their clothing from the skins and bones of beasts, and carve bone or ivory into jewelry and the handles of weapons and tools. They reuse the weapons and armor of their smaller foes, stringing shields into scale armor and lashing sword blades to wooden hafts to make giant-sized spears. The greatest battle trophies come from conquered dragons, and the greatest frost giant jarls wear armor of dragon scales or wield picks and mauls made of a dragon's teeth or claws.

entries.name: Giants
entries: Ancient empires once cast long shadows over a world that quaked beneath the giants' feet. In those lost days, these towering figures were dragon slayers, dreamers, crafters, and kings, but their kind fell from glory long ago. However, even divided among secluded clans scattered throughout the world, the giants maintain the customs and traditions of old.

entries.name: Old as Legend
entries: In remote regions of the world, the last remaining plinths, monoliths, and statues of the great giant empires bow their heads in desolate obscurity. Where once those empires sprawled across all lands, now the giants dwell in isolated tribes and clans.

Giants are almost as old as dragons, which were still young when the giants' heavy feet first shook the foundations of the world. As they spread across new lands, giants and dragons fought bitter generational wars that nearly brought both sides low. No living giant remembers what started the conflict, but myths and tales of their race's glorious dawn are still sung in their steadings and holdfasts, vilifying the primeval wyrms. Giants and dragons continue to harbor grudges against one another, and it is seldom that they will meet or occupy the same area without a fight.

entries.name: The Ordning
entries: Each of the main giant races-the cloud, fire, frost, hill, stone, and storm giants-are related by common elements of history, religion, and culture. They view one another as kindred, keeping any inherent animosity over territory and ambition to a minimum.

Giants belong to a caste structure called the ordning. Based on social class and highly organized, the ordning assigns a social rank to each giant. By understanding its place in the ordning, a giant knows which other giants are inferior or superior to it, since no two giants are equal. Each of the giant races analyzes a different combination of skills or qualities to determine the ordning. Giants make excelling in these qualities the purpose of their lives.

At the highest level of the ordning, the races of the giants are also ranked according to status. Storm giants are the highest in the ordning, followed by cloud giants, fire giants, frost giants, stone giants, hill giants, and finally giant kin such as fomorians, ettins, and ogres.

Regardless of a giant's rank among its own race, the chief of a hill giant tribe is inferior to the most common of stone giants. The lowest ranked giant of any type is superior to the highest ranked giant of an inferior type. It isn't considered evil to disrespect or even betray a giant of another type, merely rude.

entries.name: Giant Gods
entries: When the giants' ancient empires fell, Annam, father of all giants, forsook his children and the world. He swore never to look upon either again until the giants had returned to their glory and reclaimed their birthright as rulers of the world. As a result, giants pray not to Annam but to his divine children, along with a host of hero-deities and godly villains that make up the giants' pantheon.

Chief among these gods are the children of Annam, whose sons represent each type of giant: Stronmaus for storm giants, Memnor for cloud giants, Skoraeus Stonebones for stone giants, Thrym for frost giants, Surtur for fire giants, and Grolantor for hill giants. Not all giants automatically revere their kind's primary deity, however. Many good cloud giants refuse to worship the deceitful Memnor, and a storm giant dwelling in the icy mountains of the north might pay more homage to Thrym than Stronmaus. Other giants feel a stronger connection to Annam's daughters, who include Hiatea, the huntress and home warden; Iallanis, goddess of love and peace; and Diancastra, an impetuous and arrogant trickster.

Some giants abandon their own gods and fall prey to demon cults, paying homage to Baphomet or Kostchtchie. To worship them or any other non-giant deity is a great sin against the ordning, and almost certain to make a giant an outcast.

trait.name: Keen Smell
entries: The beardog has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on smell.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The beardog makes two attacks: one with its bite and one with its claws.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h} 18 ({@damage 3d8 + 5}) piercing damage and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 16}) if the target is a large or smaller creature it is also {@condition restrained}. Until this grapple ends the beardog can't bite another target.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 2d10 + 5}) slashing damage.

spellcasting.name: Cursed Spellcasting
headerEntries: The giant has a macabre collection of the heads of his fallen victmins. This Collection allows him to channel negative energy and cast spells. The giant can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material or somatic components (to hit {@hit 11}, spell save {@dc 19}):

trait.name: Shield Master
entries: If the headhunter is subjected to an effect that allows it to make a Dexterity saving throw to take only half damage, the headhunter instead takes no damage if it succeeds on the saving throw, and only half damage if it fails.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The giant casts a spell and makes two battleaxe attacks.

action.name: Battleaxe
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}33 ({@damage 6d8 + 6}) bludgeoning damage.

variant.name: New Giant Options
entries: Some adult hill giants like to hurl themselves bodily at smaller foes and crush them beneath their bulk. This ability is represented by the following action option.

entries.name: Squash
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one Medium or Smaller creature. {@h}26 ({@damage 6d6 + 5}) bludgeoning damage, the giant lands {@condition prone} in the target's space, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 16}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition prone}. The grapple ends early if the giant stands up.

trait.name: Heated Body
entries: A creature that touches the giant or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it takes 7 ({@damage 2d6}) fire damage.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The giant makes two greatsword attacks.

action.name: Flametongue
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}21 ({@damage 4d6 + 7}) slashing damage plus 14 ({@damage 4d6}) fire damage.

action.name: Molten Rock {@recharge 5}
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 13} to hit, range 150/300 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 2d10 + 7}) bludgeoning damage plus 33 ({@damage 6d10}) fire damage and each creature whitin 10 feet of the target must succeed on a {@dc 19} dexterity saving throw or take 22 ({@damage 4d10}).

action.name: Rock
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 13} to hit, range 60/240 ft., one target. {@h}29 ({@damage 6d10 + 7}) bludgeoning damage.

variant.name: New Giant Options
entries: Some adult fire giants are trained to lay siege to strongholds and break through enemy lines. These abilities are represented by the following traits.

entries.name: Siege Monster
entries: The giant deals double damage to objects and structures.

entries.name: Tackle
entries: When the giant enters any enemy's space for the first time on a turn, the enemy must succeed on a {@dc 19} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The giant's spellcasting ability is wisdom (spell save {@dc 19} {@hit 11} to hit ). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:
will: {@spell spiritual weapon} (at 5th level, as fire damage)

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The giant makes two hammer attacks.

action.name: Fire Hammer
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 12} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 2d8 + 7}) bludgeoning damage plus fire 9 ({@damage 2d8}) fire damage and the creature must succeed on a {@dc 19} Constitution saving throw or drop any metal object it is holding.
Additionally if the creature is wearing a metal armor or shield it has disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks until the start of the giant's next turn.

bonus.name: Spiritual Weapon
entries: {@atk ms} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h} 24 ({@damage 4d8 + 6}) fire damage.

variant.name: New Giant Options
entries: Some adult fire giants are trained to lay siege to strongholds and break through enemy lines. These abilities are represented by the following traits.

entries.name: Siege Monster
entries: The giant deals double damage to objects and structures.

entries.name: Tackle
entries: When the giant enters any enemy's space for the first time on a turn, the enemy must succeed on a {@dc 19} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

monster.name: Molten Iron Golem

immune.note: from nonmagical attacks that aren't adamantine

languages: understands the languages of its creator but can't speak

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: The golem is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

trait.name: Heated Weapons
entries: Any metal melee weapon the golem wields deals an extra 11 ({@damage 2d10}) fire damage on a hit.

trait.name: Everburning
entries: The golem regains 20 hit points at the start of its turn. If the golem takes cold damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of the golem's next turn. The golem dies only if it starts its turn with 0 hit points and doesn't regenerate.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The golem makes two melee attacks.

action.name: Piercer
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}20 ({@damage 3d8 + 7}) piercing damage plus 11 ({@damage 2d10}) fire damage.

action.name: Chain Hooks
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 30 ft., one target. {@h}23 ({@damage 2d10 + 7}) slashing plus 11 ({@damage 2d10}) fire damage and the target is pulled 10 feet towards the golem.

action.name: Molten Spit {@recharge 5}
entries: The golem spews molten iron in a 5-foot wide 60-foot long line. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 19} Dexterity saving throw, taking 45 ({@damage 10d8}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

trait.name: False Appearance (Hoard Form Only)
entries: If the mimic is motionless at the start of combat, it has advantage on its initiative roll. Moreover, if a creature hasn't observed the mimic move or act, that creature must succeed on a {@dc 18} Intelligence (Investigation) check to discern that the mimic is animate.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The mimic makes one Bite attack and two Pseudopod attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 30 ft., one creature. {@h}16 ({@damage 2d10 + 5}) piercing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) acid damage.

action.name: Pseudopod
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 60 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) bludgeoning damage, and the mimic adheres to the target. A creature adhered to the mimic is also {@condition grappled} by it (escape {@dc 16}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}. Ability checks made to escape this grapple have disadvantage.

action.name: Entrap {@recharge 5}
entries: The mimic sprays a fine mist of acid in a 30-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 14} Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, the creature takes 27 ({@damage 6d8}) acid damage and is {@condition blinded} until the end of its next turn. On a successful save, the creature takes half as much damage and isn't {@condition blinded}.

action.name: Shapechanger
entries: The mimic transforms into a hoard or back into its true, amorphous form. Its statistics are the same in each form. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying isn't transformed. It reverts to its true form if it dies.

Kin to the common mimic described in the {@i Monster Manual}, hoard mimics are among the oldest and most cunning of their kind. A hoard mimic's massive, amorphous form and shape-shifting prowess allow it to take on the semblance of a vast trove of treasures, not just a single object. Like smaller mimics, hoard mimics exude adhesive goo to trap prey. They can also vent a fine, caustic mist from their pores that burns and blinds creatures caught in it.

Hoard mimics are so named because many enter into partnerships with dragons, each one serving as a false hoard in a dragon's lair to draw unwitting intruders away from the real richesand into the mimic's maw. If faced with unexpectedly fierce opposition, though, a hoard mimic might offer information about the true hoard in exchange for its life.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The warlock's spellcasting ability is Charisma. It can innately cast the following spells (spell save {@dc 24}), requiring no material components:

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The warlock's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma. It can innately cast the following spells (spell save {@dc 24}), requiring no material components:

trait.name: Alien Mind
entries: If a creature tries to read the Warlocks's thoughts or deals psychic damage to it, that creature must succeed on a {@dc 24} Intelligence saving throw or be {@condition stunned} for 1 minute. The {@condition stunned} creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

trait.name: Create Thrall
entries: The Warlock can infect a creature's mind and body with the alien magic of his patron. As a bonus action the Warlock touch an {@condition unconscious} humanoid or beast. The creature is transformed into the splitting image of the warlock, its statistics become the {@creature Warlock of the Great Old One|VGM} and is immune to {@condition Exhaustion}, following the Warlock's commands and will.
The creature remains in this form until it falls to 0 hit points or fall {@condition unconscious}.
This effect can be ended with a {@spell dispel magic} spell {@dc 19}, the creature then falls {@condition unconscious} with 0 hit points.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The warlock has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Cloak of Flies
entries: As a bonus action, the warlock can surround himself with a magical aura that looks like buzzing flies, any creature that starts its turn within 5 feet of the warlock takes 10 poison damage.
